awd_titl_txt: I-Corps Sites - Type I: NYU I-Corps Sites for Enhancing Diversity in Entrepreneurship
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, from New York University (NYU), creates an I-Corps Site at this institution. Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors.

NYU Tandon School of Engineering (NYU-SoE) Center for Innovation and Entrepreneurship (CIE) will "encourage and support diversity in STEM entrepreneurship, among women in particular, by encouraging social entrepreneurship, an approach that has shown to be attractive to women." Using the Lean LaunchPad approach infused with insights into supporting diversity, teams will receive funding for customer discovery, prototyping, and other resources to support commercialization across multiple academic terms. This approach is supported by a strong network of faculty and mentors who have exhibited an excellent record of previous NSF funding and commercialization successes.

The intellectual merit of this proposal incorporates the proposition that social entrepreneurship is more attractive to underrepresented groups, particularly women. By pursuing avenues that will increase diversity in both STEM and entrepreneurship, through the training, programs, and mentorship of the site, this project may serve as an exemplar for I-Corps nationally.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Within our institution we aimed to increase diversity in Entrepreneurship with a focus on STEM. Through direct outreach, and partnering with others on campus who have cultivated networks of entrepreneurially inclined students, researchers and faculty, such as the NYU Entrepreneurial Institute (NYU Office of the Provost), Berkley Innovation Labs (Stern School of Business), Tandon Makerspace (Tandon School of Engineering), we were able to develop a bootcamp style lean launchpad curriculum. We incentivized participants efforts in hopes to not only increase participation, but to further help with their customer discovery efforts

We started off having a 4-week summer I-corps sites program that met 3 times a week, but based on feedback we changed it to 2-week (all 10 days) for student oriented January-term Sprint and Summer Sprint. We also added  a 1-week (all 5 days) program for the faculty-oriented sprint, which later became our Tech Venture Workshop which met once a week for 3 consecutive weeks. 

In doing so we would survey participants prior to the start of the program and again at the end. We probed the following metrics: gender and racial identity, diversity of schools, type of technology, whether it is their first time participating in Lean methodology, their knowledge of the Business model canvas,  growth mindset and whether they identified & validated the market. 

After 18 cohorts to date, our efforts have allowed us to train 224 student/faculty teams consisting of 596 participants. 65.27% (389/596)  were women/underrepresented minorities. Due to the pandemic we added specific questions to our surveys to see if there was a direct impact on participation. While responses were mixed we were able to conclude that remote learning definitely impacted female participation. The uncertainty of the pandemic caused a decrease in student participation because they were hesitant to add to their workload despite increased funding awards to further incentivize increased participation.

Although our award has ended, we will continue to probe and assess our collected data in attempts to put together a longitudinal study. Many of the participants continued on with their startup venture pursuing various other funding opportunities and awards. In terms of diversity and inclusion, representation seems to play a big factor in increasing participation.


 


Last Modified: 05/31/2022
Modified by: Jin K Montclare
